bibl.title: Letter from Victor G. Heiser to Henry Rose Carter, December 4, 1924

div1.p: Heiser sends a detailed report on the Malaria conference in New Orleans, Louisiana. He discusses malaria treatment, control, and mosquitoes.

December 4, 1924
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Many thanks for your note of November 24. Unfortu-
nately it did not reach me until my return from New Orleans,
so I did not have an opportunity to extend your greetings to
those who attended the Malaria Conference. It will be no
news to you, I am sure, that every mention of your name at
the Conference evoked approval and applause which finally found
concrete expression in your election for life as Honorary
President of the National Malaria Committee.

The Conference was a great success, and there was
more sustained interest than I have ever seen at a medical
meeting anywhere in the world. There were never less than
seventy-five in attendance. Those who had something to say,
said it without urging. Practically all of those who talked
had experience with the subject they were discussing. It was
a bad thing for anyone to take the floor who was not thorough-
ly familiar with his subject, because his ignorance was sure
Dr. H.R. Carter
- 2 -
December 4, 1924
to be exposed by subsequent speakers.

It seemed to be the consensus of opinion of those at-
tending the Conference that quinine does not prevent malaria
infections, and that under ideal conditions it is very much
better to withhold quinine until definite symptoms have de-
veloped and then apply treatment. Ideal conditions, of course,
do not happen often, and it is more than likely that quinine
given in a so-called prophylactic way would have to be continued,
because if persisted in long enough quinine will cure the in-
fection after it has once been contracted. There was also gen-
eral agreement that malaria control work should not be under-
taken without first having a careful survey, and that those
experienced in malaria control should define the problem and
decide upon the measures to be taken. Darling's method for
spleen examination had much favorable comment. Maxcy and
Smillie also frequently brought to the attention of the Con-
ference the need of a malariologist with each State Board of
Health in the South. The control of malaria in tide-water
counties like those of North Carolina still seems to be a dis-
couraging undertaking. However, some figures were available
which seemed to show that a 30% improvement had been made in
a few such counties in North Carolina. It was much emphasized
Dr. H.R. Carter
- 3 -
December 4, 1924
that a thoroughly well-balanced ration and treatment for com-
plications, such as hookworm disease, are essential if re-
lapses are to be held to a minimum. For the Piedmont area, at
least, it seems to have been fairly well established that A.
quadrimaculatus is the mosquito almost solely concerned in the
transmission of malaria. Barber's report on the small amount
of malaria he found in Louisiana, particularly in the rice
field area, came as a surprise to most of us. The discovery
by Paul Russell of a definite method for differentiating the
larvae of quadrimaculatus of A. punctipennis and A. crucians
was a very distinct contribution. It was also another illus-
tration of the capacity of doctors to do successful work in
other fields of science.

With the hope that everything is going well with you,
and with cordial good wishes, I am,
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, Victor G. Heiser Dr. H.R. Carter,
2122 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
